dating.remarks: [Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, revised 2016]

pageContext.description:
The graceful nude figure of Charity shown seated on a tree stump with her legs daintily crossed is embraced from behind by a young boy who she in turn supports with her left arm. Her head is tilted forward. A transparent veil covers her fashionably combed blond hair that falls in elaborate waves on either side. The veil extends over her high forehead to the almond shaped eyes that gaze dreamily at the viewer. A further child sits on her right knee and sucks on her right breast. A girl approaches from the left with an apple in her right hand and eats another apple held in her left hand. To the right of Charity another boy sits in front of the tree stump, holding an apple in his left hand and looking to the left. In the upper left quarter of the painting a landscape is visible with a castle on a rocky outcrop and a town located on a river or lake.
[Michel Polfer, in Exhib. Cat. Paderborn 2015, No. 86] [Translation, cda 2016]

metadata.title: Charity

pageContext.owner: Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg
pageContext.provenance:
- Berlin, Ulrich H. Jäger
- 1928 Frankfurt, J. Rosenbaum
[Friedländer, Rosenberg 1979, No. 406B]
- before 1933: Collection of Edmond Reiffers (Luxembourg)
- End of 1940/ before vor 6.10.1941: Collection of SS-Obersturmbannführer Kajetan Mühlmann
- seized by the allied troops at Schloss Volders/Tyrol, Mühlmann's residence, at the end of the war 
- Dec. 1946: restored to Grand Dutchy of Luxembourg 
- 15.1.1947: transferred to the MNHA collection by government's resolution
[Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, revised 2016]
pageContext.repository: Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- woodworm visible on the back and in raking light beneath the paint layer
- original support thinned
- small paint losses; retouchings
- varnish is slightly brittle

tests.text:
- thickness of panel: 4 mm (not original thickness)
- 2 planks: a) 15.5 (17) x 49.9 cm; b) 18 (16.5) x 49.9 cm
- dovetail joint (4x)
- [almost] original size?; thin wooden batten (7mm) added to the bottom of the panel
- cradle (5x vertical, 6 x horizontal members => removed due to damage caused (4.3.2002)

- whitish, creamy coloured ground applied over the entire panel to the edge
- no incised lines
- some drying cracks
- not readily visible in normal light

- very thin application in the flesh paint leaving the ground visible
- no fingerprints visible

- new frame and microclimate box (64 x 46.5 x 8 cm)
- wood & gilded

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia at the lower right edge, on the tree stump: serpent with dropped wings, facing left; in yellow paint
[cda 2016]
